conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the rod and how they affect its motion.
Gravitational force acting along the incline is mg sin θ.
Magnetic force opposing the motion is F_mag = BIL = B^2L^2v/(R+r).
Rod reaches maximum velocity v_m when magnetic force equals gravitational force.
Maximum velocity v_m is mg(R+r) sin θ/B^2L^2.
Net force on the rod is mg sin θ - B^2L^2v/(R+r) = ma.
Acceleration a is g sin θ - B^2L^2v/(m(R+r)).
Differential equation for velocity is dv/dt = g sin θ - B^2L^2v/(m(R+r)).
Solve the differential equation by separating variables and integrating.
Velocity as a function of time is v(t) = v_m (1 - e^(-B^2L^2/(m(R+r))t)).
Rod approaches maximum speed asymptotically as exponential term approaches zero.
Time t for rod to reach maximum speed is approximately m(R+r)/(B^2L^2).
